narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Andrew John Muehleisen  Andrew was organized and accessible
Instructor: Andrew John Muehleisen  Andrew was very helpful in answering questions.
Instructor: Andrew John Muehleisen  He was helpful the few times that I asked him for help.
Instructor: Andrew John Muehleisen  Andrew was great. Knowledgeable but also knew when he didn't know, and directed us to Simon. Very helpful and accessible.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Simon knows a lot but is not good at explaining things.

I think the class would have benefited from more problem sets and weekly assignments. It was difficult to pay attention a lot of the time in class because the professor was hard to hear and hard to follow. That said, Simon was very receptive to feedback and very responsive when asked questions over email, or in person. He was very available but it was difficult to self-motivate to keep up with the course work without weekly assignments.

(Q2) Out of work class was never graded (except for exams and projects) and didn't feel very helpful for a range of analyses. Examples were very specific for one thing but weren't always readily translated for other uses. I would have liked more emphasis on understanding the information throughout instead of relying on a few conglomerated assessments at the end.
Simon was a good professor - he seems a little uncomfortable at times. He was good one on one.

Prof. Queenborough is clearly knows the topic well, but the lecture essentially consisted of him running through problems on the project screen in front of the class. There was not enough engagement with the students nor explanation of the detail of the code we were learning.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: This course is a great introduction to the software R. I went from zero knowledge of coding to being able to run statistical analyses and organize data. R is a useful and powerful tool.
R is a useful skill and the examples are helpful.
-Class exercises led by the instructor
We did a lot of exercises in class which are useful and way of learning by doing it.
I learned a lot during the mid-term and mini-project.
Good skill to learn.
-Learning R on my own
R is a useful tool to learn.
I learned how to use R!
Relatively light work load, learned a good amount about how to use R Software which is a valuable skill.
The best aspects of the course were working with real-life data and also the availability of resource on the instructor's webpage.
Methodically reviewing steps in working with R.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I think this course should begin with a simple overview of coding language. I was lost in the beginning trying to distinguish functions from arguments, and types of arguments, etc. That might only take 30 mins in the first class, but it would be very valuable for people like me that had no experience with coding at all.
Instructor needs to explain things better.
- Classroom was too big and not suited for teaching a course like R statistical programs. A more closer room would be preferable.
Since it was a lot of following along- if you messed up a part of the R code- it would be easy to fall behind in class.

-The head instructor was awful, particularly: --He had frequent problems with the microphone...daily, throughout the entire semester. This wasted class time and quickly went from entertaining to irritating as the semester went on. --I used to be a teacher, I know it's a challenge. However, he did not rise to this challenge. He was really unable at making the content accessible to students. It is programming, but it needn't be taught in such a dry manner. Truly mind-numbing and did not demonstrate creative effort. Programming can be really interesting --I recommend finding an instructor who demonstrates more outward excitement about R / programming. I would never take this class again, nor would I recommend it to other students; not because of the content, but because of the instructor.

Needs a drastic improvement in organization. Programming takes time and practice and when the instructor is only looking at your code personally a few times and mostly at the end of the semester, it isn't a very helpful way to go about learning if you are doing it right, making mistakes, or how you could be doing better. I would like less lecture (it's completely ineffective for something like this) and more guided work. For example, I would like things to be broken down by week. Go over 1-2 new things per week, each building on something from previous weeks. Homework assignments and in-class work (NOT in-class lecture covering a problem all together, it doesn't help to just copy and paste code, you don't learn how to do it on your own) that can be reviewed by instructors/TAs for comprehension. I'm fine withe exams and projects, but I feel like there should be more individual assessment prior to those. Overall it was a confusing course that wasn't easy to follow.

In lecture, it would be great if Simon could speak more loudly and clearly. Also - I would recommend having short required exercises for students to do. Maybe even just they get credit for trying. That might help faciliated interactivness and questions.

Professor Queenborough's teaching style. There was little incentive to work on exercises outside of class, as we would just be discussing them in future classes. In addition, often the Prof. would walk us through problems without explaining the lines of code he was using in sufficient detail. It would be nice to know what each piece of code represented, what it could be substituted with, what kinds of object can be used for different functions, etc.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Good
Sessions where we worked on our projects were super helpful.
N/A
The course was highly practical so it offered students the opportunity extensive practice.
Yes, they were helpful - lectures + exercises in class

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am pursuing a research-based degree, and knowing how to use R is essential for running my own statistics. I definitely benefited from learning R through this class.
I am taking a lot of quantitative courses which requires application of R and therefore , this course was very useful for assisting me in performing well in other courses.
Learning R is essential to doing data analysis in ecology and forestry. This course provided the basics I needed to do analysis in R.
-R and similar programming skills are absolutely necessary for quantitative analysis in the environmental field.

As a public health student, it was useful to learn another coding language but it was difficult to translate what was happening with forestry-related items and health data (there are a lot more missing values in health data).
I'm interested in doing applied research, and being able to use a versatile, powerful, open-source software like R could be very helpful.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to take a class that focused on how to use R, rather than a class that used R as a side tool
Because R statistical package is now widely used for data analysis and it would help me with my research.
To familiarize with R package if I ever have to use it.
I need to learn R to analyze data- it is the primary program used during data analysis in ecology and forestry.
I wanted to learn R for my research project and for my future publication - this course helped me accomplish this!
See question 20.
I already knew SAS so I wanted to learn another code.
I'm interested in doing applied research, and being able to use a versatile, powerful, open-source software like R could be very helpful.
I wanted to be familiar with the R statistical package.
To become more adept at using R with ease and know-how

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Participate actively in class and do all the exercises!
-Don't do it. Find R / programming in a different department because F&ES lacks robust instructors for R, GIS, and similar programming-based skills courses.
Only do it if you're really self-motivated cause nothing about the class will keep you going unless you really want to.
Take if you want to learn R. Spend time out of class and prepping to get the most of the class. Come to class with questions.

You should have at least a general background in stats before taking this class, or be taking a stats course concurrently. You have to be relatively self-directed to learn in this class, and the midterm and final are VERY time consuming. The skills you gain from the class are definitely useful, though.

I highly recommend this course for all students, particularly first year students. I recommend the course be made one of the foundation courses. Expertise in R statistical software is crucial to performing statistical analysis. This course gives participants the confidence to use the R software.The instructor is very knowledgeable in using the software.
